name: rice
description: Rice is the seed of the grass species Oryza sativa. As a cereal grain, it is the most widely consumed staple food for a large part of the world's human population, especially in Asia. It is the agricultural commodity with the third-highest worldwide production, after sugarcane and maize.
soilRequirements: Clayey loam or clayey soil is best for rice cultivation as it ensures water retention. The soil should be deep, fertile, and have a good water-holding capacity.
growingSeason: Rice is typically grown in the rainy season (kharif) in tropical regions, though some varieties can be grown year-round with proper irrigation.
yield: Average yield is about 4-6 tons per hectare depending on the variety and cultivation practices.
uses: Staple food crop in many cultures
Rice flour for baking and cooking
marketValue: Rice prices vary by type and quality, but globally average around $300-500 per ton.

name: wheat
description: Raw wheat can be ground into flour or, using hard durum wheat only, can be ground into semolina, germinated and dried creating malt, crushed and de-branned into groats, or steamed, dried, crushed and de-branned into bulgur also known as groats.
soilRequirements: Wheat grows best in well-drained loamy to clayey loam soils with good organic matter content. The soil should be deep enough to hold moisture but not waterlogged.
growingSeason: Winter wheat is sown in fall and harvested in summer, while spring wheat is sown in spring and harvested in late summer.
yield: Average yield is about 3-5 tons per hectare depending on variety and cultivation practices.
uses: Flour for bread, pasta, and baked goods
Wheat germ and bran for health foods
marketValue: Wheat prices typically range from $150-300 per ton depending on quality and market conditions.

name: maize
description: Maize (corn) is a cereal grain first domesticated by indigenous peoples in southern Mexico. The leafy stalk of the plant produces pollen inflorescences and separate ovuliferous inflorescences called ears that yield kernels or seeds, which are fruits.
soilRequirements: Maize thrives in well-drained, fertile soils with good organic matter content. Sandy loam to loamy soils with good water-holding capacity are ideal.
growingSeason: Maize is typically grown in spring and summer, with a growing season of 90-120 days depending on the variety.
yield: Average yield is about 5-8 tons per hectare depending on variety and cultivation practices.
uses: Corn flour and meal for cooking
marketValue: Maize prices typically range from $150-250 per ton depending on quality and market conditions.

name: chickpea
description: Chickpea is a high-protein legume crop and is one of the earliest cultivated legumes. It's a key ingredient in many Middle Eastern and Indian cuisines and provides a good source of protein for vegetarian diets.
soilRequirements: Chickpeas prefer well-drained, sandy loam to loamy soils with neutral to slightly alkaline pH. They do not tolerate waterlogged conditions.
growingSeason: In tropical regions, chickpeas are typically grown as a winter crop (rabi season). The growing period is about 90-120 days.
yield: Average yield is about 1-2 tons per hectare depending on variety and cultivation practices.
uses: Whole cooked chickpeas in salads and dishes
marketValue: Chickpea prices typically range from $500-900 per ton depending on quality and market conditions.

name: kidneybeans
description: Kidney beans are a variety of the common bean (Phaseolus vulgaris) named for their visual resemblance to kidneys. They are particularly valued for their high protein and fiber content.
soilRequirements: Kidney beans grow best in well-drained, loamy soils with good organic matter content. They prefer slightly acidic to neutral pH soils.
growingSeason: Kidney beans are typically grown in summer when there is no risk of frost. The growing period is about 90-120 days.
yield: Average yield is about 1.5-2.5 tons per hectare depending on variety and cultivation practices.
uses: Cooked in various dishes and stews
Ground into flour for specialty foods
marketValue: Kidney bean prices typically range from $600-1000 per ton depending on quality and market conditions.

name: pigeonpeas
description: Pigeon pea is a perennial legume from the family Fabaceae. It is cultivated for its edible seeds, which are an important source of protein in many countries, especially in South Asia and East Africa.
soilRequirements: Pigeon peas can grow in a wide range of soils but prefer well-drained, light to medium soils. They are notably drought-tolerant once established.
growingSeason: Pigeon peas are typically sown at the beginning of the rainy season and can take 6-9 months to mature depending on the variety.
yield: Average yield is about 1-2 tons per hectare depending on variety and cultivation practices.
uses: Dried and stored for long periods
marketValue: Pigeon pea prices typically range from $500-900 per ton depending on quality and market conditions.

name: mothbeans
description: Moth bean is a drought-resistant legume crop primarily grown in arid and semi-arid regions. It is an important pulse crop in parts of India, particularly Rajasthan, and is valued for its high nutritional content.
soilRequirements: Moth beans thrive in sandy to sandy loam soils with good drainage. They are extremely drought-tolerant and can grow in poor soils where other crops might fail.
growingSeason: Moth beans are typically grown during the rainy season (kharif) with a growing period of about 60-90 days.
yield: Average yield is about 0.5-1.5 tons per hectare depending on cultivation practices.
uses: Whole cooked beans in various dishes
Ground into flour for snacks and sweets
marketValue: Moth bean prices typically range from $500-800 per ton depending on quality and market conditions.

name: mungbean
description: Mung bean is a plant species in the legume family. The mung bean is mainly cultivated in East Asia, Southeast Asia and the Indian subcontinent. It is used as an ingredient in both savory and sweet dishes.
soilRequirements: Mung beans prefer well-drained loamy soils with good organic matter content. They can tolerate moderate fertility but not waterlogged conditions.
growingSeason: Mung beans are typically grown in summer and have a short growing period of 60-90 days.
yield: Average yield is about 1-1.5 tons per hectare depending on variety and cultivation practices.
uses: Bean sprouts for salads and stir-fries
Whole cooked beans in various dishes
Ground into flour for noodles and pancakes
marketValue: Mung bean prices typically range from $700-1200 per ton depending on quality and market conditions.

name: blackgram
description: Black gram, also known as urad dal, is a bean grown in the Indian subcontinent. It is highly prized for its nutritional value and is used in many traditional Indian dishes, particularly in South Indian cuisine.
soilRequirements: Black gram grows best in well-drained loamy soils with good organic matter content. It can tolerate a range of soil conditions but not waterlogging.
growingSeason: Black gram is typically grown in both kharif (rainy) and rabi (winter) seasons depending on the region. The growing period is about 90-120 days.
yield: Average yield is about 1-1.5 tons per hectare depending on variety and cultivation practices.
uses: Whole or split as dal in curries
Ground into flour for flatbreads and snacks
marketValue: Black gram prices typically range from $800-1300 per ton depending on quality and market conditions.

name: lentil
description: Lentils are legumes that are rich in protein, fiber, and various nutrients. They have the second-highest ratio of protein to food energy among legumes, exceeded only by soybeans. Lentils are an important part of diets in many parts of the world.
soilRequirements: Lentils prefer well-drained loamy to clayey loam soils with good fertility. They can tolerate moderately alkaline soils but not acidic or waterlogged conditions.
growingSeason: Lentils are typically grown as a cool-season crop in winter or early spring. The growing period is about 80-110 days.
yield: Average yield is about 1-2 tons per hectare depending on variety and cultivation practices.
uses: Ground into flour for various dishes
Used in vegetarian patties and loaves
marketValue: Lentil prices typically range from $600-1100 per ton depending on variety, quality, and market conditions.

name: pomegranate
description: Pomegranate is a fruit-bearing deciduous shrub in the family Lythraceae. The edible fruit is a berry with seeds and pulp produced in the flower's ovary. The fruit is rich in antioxidants and has been associated with many health benefits.
soilRequirements: Pomegranates prefer well-drained, deep loamy soils with good fertility. They can tolerate slightly acidic to slightly alkaline soils and some salinity.
growingSeason: Pomegranates are perennial plants that typically flower in spring and produce fruit that ripens in fall.
yield: Mature trees can yield 50-150 kg of fruit per tree depending on variety and cultivation practices.
marketValue: Pomegranate prices typically range from $1000-2500 per ton depending on quality and market conditions.

name: banana
description: Banana is an edible fruit produced by several kinds of large herbaceous flowering plants in the genus Musa. The fruit is variable in size, color, and firmness, but is usually elongated and curved, with soft flesh rich in starch covered with a rind, which may be green, yellow, red, purple, or brown when ripe.
soilRequirements: Bananas require deep, well-drained loamy soils with high organic matter content. They prefer slightly acidic to neutral pH and need good moisture retention capacity.
growingSeason: Bananas are perennial plants that produce fruit year-round in suitable conditions. From planting to harvest typically takes 9-12 months.
yield: A single banana plant can produce 20-40 kg of fruit depending on variety and cultivation practices.
marketValue: Banana prices typically range from $300-700 per ton depending on variety, quality, and market conditions.

name: mango
description: Mango is one of the most important and widely cultivated fruits of the tropical world. It is native to South Asia and has been cultivated for thousands of years in the Indian subcontinent. The fruit is prized for its sweet flavor and high nutritional value.
soilRequirements: Mangoes prefer deep, well-drained loamy soils with good fertility. They can tolerate a wide range of soil types but not waterlogging or highly alkaline conditions.
growingSeason: Mangoes are perennial trees that typically flower in early spring and bear fruit in summer. Trees begin bearing fruit after 3-5 years.
yield: A mature mango tree can yield 200-300 kg of fruit annually depending on variety and cultivation practices.
marketValue: Mango prices typically range from $800-2000 per ton depending on variety, quality, and market conditions.

name: grapes
description: Grapes are a non-climacteric fruit that grow on woody vines of the genus Vitis. They can be eaten fresh as table grapes, used for making wine, jam, grape juice, jelly, grape seed extract, vinegar, and grape seed oil.
soilRequirements: Grapes grow best in deep, well-drained soils with good organic matter content. They prefer loamy or sandy loam soils with good drainage.
growingSeason: Grapes are perennial vines that typically begin producing fruit in their third year. The growing season varies by region, but generally runs from spring through fall.
yield: A mature vineyard can yield 8-12 tons per hectare depending on variety and cultivation practices.
marketValue: Grape prices typically range from $700-3000 per ton depending on variety, quality, and whether for table or wine production.

name: watermelon
description: Watermelon is a flowering plant species of the Cucurbitaceae family and the name of its edible fruit. It is a highly cultivated fruit worldwide, with more than 1,000 varieties. Watermelon is a sweet and refreshing low-calorie summer snack.
soilRequirements: Watermelons grow best in light, well-drained, sandy loam soils with good organic matter content. They do not tolerate heavy, clayey soils or waterlogged conditions.
growingSeason: Watermelons are warm-season annuals typically planted after all danger of frost has passed. From planting to harvest typically takes 80-110 days.
yield: Average yield is about 20-30 tons per hectare depending on variety and cultivation practices.
uses: Seeds can be roasted and eaten
marketValue: Watermelon prices typically range from $200-400 per ton depending on quality and market conditions.

name: muskmelon
description: Muskmelon (Cucumis melo) is a species of melon that includes cantaloupe, honeydew, and several other varieties. It is known for its sweet taste and aromatic flesh that ranges from pale green to deep orange.
soilRequirements: Muskmelons prefer well-drained, sandy loam soils rich in organic matter. They do not tolerate heavy clay soils or waterlogged conditions.
growingSeason: Muskmelons are warm-season annuals that are planted after all danger of frost has passed. The growing period is about 70-90 days from planting to harvest.
yield: Average yield is about 15-25 tons per hectare depending on variety and cultivation practices.
uses: Seeds can be dried and eaten
marketValue: Muskmelon prices typically range from $300-700 per ton depending on variety, quality, and market conditions.

name: mango
description: Mango is one of the most important and widely cultivated fruits of the tropical world. It is native to South Asia and has been cultivated for thousands of years in the Indian subcontinent. The fruit is prized for its sweet flavor and high nutritional value.
soilRequirements: Mangoes prefer deep, well-drained loamy soils with good fertility. They can tolerate a wide range of soil types but not waterlogging or highly alkaline conditions.
growingSeason: Mangoes are perennial trees that typically flower in early spring and bear fruit in summer. Trees begin bearing fruit after 3-5 years.
yield: A mature mango tree can yield 200-300 kg of fruit annually depending on variety and cultivation practices.
marketValue: Mango prices typically range from $800-2000 per ton depending on variety, quality, and market conditions.

name: apple
description: Apple (Malus domestica) is one of the most widely cultivated and consumed fruits globally. Originating from Central Asia, apples have been grown for thousands of years in Asia and Europe. They are renowned for their crisp texture, sweet to tart flavor, and significant nutritional value.
soilRequirements: Apples thrive in well-drained, deep loamy soils rich in organic matter. The optimal soil pH ranges from 6.0 to 7.0. Soils should have good aeration and fertility, avoiding waterlogging conditions.
growingSeason: Apple trees require a chilling period of approximately 1000 hours below 7°C to break dormancy. Flowering occurs in early spring, with fruit maturing in late summer to autumn. Trees typically begin bearing fruit after 3-5 years.
yield: A mature apple tree can yield between 100 to 300 kg of fruit annually, depending on the variety and cultivation practices.
marketValue: Apple prices vary based on variety, quality, and market conditions, typically ranging from $600 to $1500 per ton.

name: orange
description: Orange (*Citrus sinensis*) is a globally cultivated citrus fruit, renowned for its sweet flavor and high vitamin C content. Originating from Southeast Asia, it is now widely grown in tropical and subtropical regions, playing a significant role in global agriculture.
soilRequirements: Oranges thrive in well-drained, deep loamy soils with a pH between 6.0 and 7.5. Sandy loam or loamy soils are ideal. Proper drainage is essential to prevent root diseases.
growingSeason: Orange trees are typically planted in spring or early summer. They begin bearing fruit 3–5 years after planting, with harvesting occurring in late autumn to winter, depending on the variety and region.
yield: A mature orange tree can yield approximately 200–400 fruits per season. With optimal care, yields can reach up to 600 fruits per tree annually.
marketValue: Orange prices vary based on variety, quality, and market conditions, typically ranging from $500 to $1500 per ton.

name: papaya
description: Papaya (*Carica papaya*) is a fast-growing tropical fruit tree native to Central America, now widely cultivated in tropical and subtropical regions worldwide. Known for its sweet, orange-fleshed fruit rich in vitamins A and C, papaya is valued for both its nutritional and medicinal properties.
soilRequirements: Papaya thrives in well-drained, sandy loam soils rich in organic matter. The optimal soil pH ranges from 6.0 to 6.5. Waterlogging and salinity should be avoided, as papaya is sensitive to both conditions.
growingSeason: Papaya can be cultivated year-round in tropical climates. The plants typically begin bearing fruit 6 to 10 months after planting, with peak production occurring in the second year. The economic lifespan of a papaya plantation is about 3 to 4 years.
yield: A mature papaya tree can produce between 30 to 150 fruits annually, depending on the variety and cultivation practices. This equates to approximately 35 to 50 tons per hectare per year.
uses: Culinary ingredient in salads and desserts
marketValue: Papaya prices vary based on region, quality, and market demand, typically ranging from $300 to $800 per ton.

name: coconut
description: Coconut (*Cocos nucifera*) is a tropical palm tree cultivated extensively in coastal and humid regions worldwide. Renowned for its versatility, the coconut provides food, oil, fiber, and timber. It thrives in sandy soils and is integral to the economies of many tropical countries.
soilRequirements: Coconut palms prefer well-drained sandy loam soils with good water-holding capacity. They tolerate a wide pH range (5.2–8.6) and can grow in coastal alluviums and river valleys. Proper drainage is essential to prevent root diseases.
growingSeason: Coconuts can be planted year-round in tropical climates, with the onset of the rainy season being ideal. Trees begin bearing fruit 6–7 years after planting, with peak production occurring between 15–20 years.
yield: A mature coconut tree typically yields 50–80 nuts per year. Under optimal conditions, yields can reach up to 100–150 nuts annually. Plantations with 150 trees per hectare can produce approximately 9,000 coconuts per year.
marketValue: Coconut prices vary based on product type and region, typically ranging from $300 to $800 per ton for raw nuts.

name: cotton
description: Cotton is a soft, fluffy staple fiber that grows in a boll around the seeds of cotton plants of the genus Gossypium. It is a major cash crop and one of the most important textile fibers in the world.
soilRequirements: Cotton grows best in deep, well-drained, sandy loam to clay loam soils with good organic matter content. It can tolerate moderate salinity and alkalinity.
growingSeason: Cotton is typically planted in spring and harvested in fall. The growing period is about 150-180 days from planting to harvest.
yield: Average yield is about 2-3 tons of seed cotton per hectare depending on variety and cultivation practices.
marketValue: Cotton prices typically range from $1500-2500 per ton depending on quality, staple length, and market conditions.

name: jute
description: Jute is a long, soft, shiny bast fiber that can be spun into coarse, strong threads. It is one of the most affordable natural fibers and is second only to cotton in production quantity. Jute is used chiefly to make cloth for wrapping bales, sacks, and coarse cloth.
soilRequirements: Jute grows best in alluvial soils with good water-holding capacity. It thrives in loamy to clayey loam soils with good organic matter content.
growingSeason: Jute is typically grown during the rainy season (monsoon) in tropical regions. The growing period is about 120-150 days.
yield: Average yield is about 2-3 tons of dry fiber per hectare depending on variety and cultivation practices.
marketValue: Jute prices typically range from $400-700 per ton depending on quality and market conditions.

name: coffee
description: Coffee is a brewed drink prepared from roasted coffee beans, the seeds of berries from certain flowering plants in the Coffea genus. Coffee plants are cultivated in over 70 countries, primarily in the equatorial regions of the Americas, Southeast Asia, the Indian subcontinent, and Africa.
soilRequirements: Coffee grows best in well-drained, deep volcanic soils rich in organic matter. The soil should have good water-holding capacity but not be waterlogged.
growingSeason: Coffee is a perennial crop. Trees begin bearing fruit after 3-5 years and remain productive for 20-30 years. Flowering typically occurs after the rainy season.
yield: Average yield is about 1-2 tons of green coffee beans per hectare depending on variety and cultivation practices.
marketValue: Coffee prices typically range from $2000-6000 per ton depending on variety (Arabica/Robusta), quality, and market conditions.
